questions.stem: A psychologist is treating a client with major depressive disorder using Beck's cognitive therapy. During a session, the client states, 'I failed one exam, so I'll never succeed in graduate school.' The therapist identifies this as a cognitive distortion. Which distortion is best illustrated by this statement?
questions.explanation: Overgeneralization involves drawing a sweeping conclusion from a single event. The client takes one exam failure and generalizes it to the entirety of graduate school. Catastrophizing would involve predicting the worst possible outcome (e.g., 'I'll be expelled and never get a job'). Personalization involves attributing external events to oneself without basis. Emotional reasoning involves using feelings as evidence of truth.

questions.stem: In Ellis's REBT, a client believes 'My boss absolutely must treat me fairly at all times, and it is awful and unbearable when he doesn't.' According to Ellis, which category of irrational belief is MOST central to this client's disturbance?
questions.explanation: According to Ellis, demandingness (absolute musts, shoulds, and oughts) is the core irrational belief from which all others derive. The statement 'My boss absolutely must treat me fairly' is a demand about others. While the statement also contains awfulizing ('it is awful') and low frustration tolerance ('unbearable'), Ellis considered demandingness the primary, most central irrational belief that generates the secondary derivatives.

questions.stem: A therapist using Beck's cognitive therapy asks a depressed client, 'What is the evidence that you are a total failure? What evidence might suggest otherwise? Is there an alternative way to think about this?' This technique is best described as:
questions.explanation: Socratic questioning is Beck's signature technique -- a method of guided discovery through a series of questions that help the client examine evidence for and against their beliefs and arrive at their own conclusions. Direct disputation is Ellis's technique, which is more confrontational and directive. Socratic questioning distinguishes Beck from Ellis: Beck guides discovery; Ellis directly challenges irrational beliefs.

questions.stem: A client in cognitive therapy reports, 'I feel anxious, which proves that something terrible is about to happen.' The therapist identifies this as which cognitive distortion?
questions.explanation: Emotional reasoning involves using one's emotional state as evidence for reality -- 'I feel it, therefore it must be true.' The client uses anxiety as proof that danger is imminent. Mind reading involves assuming knowledge of others' thoughts. Selective abstraction involves focusing on one detail while ignoring the bigger picture. Magnification involves inflating the importance of negative events.

questions.stem: Meichenbaum's self-instructional training was originally developed for which population, and it is based on which developmental theorist's model of internalized speech?

options.text: Anxious adults; based on Piaget's model of egocentric speech
Impulsive children; based on Vygotsky's model of internalized speech
Depressed adolescents; based on Erikson's model of identity formation
Children with autism; based on Bandura's model of self-regulation

questions.explanation: Meichenbaum's self-instructional training was originally developed for impulsive children and follows Vygotsky's developmental model of speech internalization: external speech by an adult model, then guided overt self-speech, then faded whispered speech, and finally covert (internal) self-instructions. This sequence bridges behavioral and cognitive interventions.

questions.stem: Select all that apply. Which of the following are components of Beck's cognitive triad of depression?

options.text: Negative view of one's physical health

questions.explanation: Beck's cognitive triad of depression consists of negative views of: (1) the self ('I'm worthless'), (2) the world ('Everything is terrible'), and (3) the future ('Things will never get better'). While depressed individuals may have negative views about health or relationships, these are not the three specific components of Beck's cognitive triad. This triad is specific to depression, not anxiety or other disorders.

questions.stem: Select all that apply. Which of the following correctly distinguish Beck's cognitive therapy from Ellis's REBT?

options.text: Beck uses Socratic questioning while Ellis uses direct disputation
Ellis focuses on irrational beliefs characterized by musts and shoulds
Beck's approach is more empirical and research-driven
Beck's therapy targets only automatic thoughts and never addresses deeper schemas
Ellis's approach avoids all behavioral techniques

questions.explanation: Beck uses Socratic questioning (guided discovery); Ellis uses direct, confrontational disputation. Ellis focuses on irrational beliefs (musts/shoulds/demands); Beck focuses on automatic thoughts, intermediate beliefs, and schemas. Beck's approach is more empirically oriented. Option D is wrong because Beck targets all three levels of cognition including core beliefs/schemas. Option E is wrong because REBT includes behavioral techniques (the 'B' in REBT stands for Behavior).

questions.stem: Select all that apply. According to Beck, which of the following are levels of cognition in his cognitive model, listed from surface level to deepest?
questions.explanation: Beck identified three levels of cognition: (1) automatic thoughts (surface-level, spontaneous cognitions), (2) intermediate beliefs (conditional rules and assumptions like 'If I don't succeed, I'm worthless'), and (3) core beliefs/schemas (deep, fundamental beliefs about self, others, and the world). Unconscious drives are Freudian concepts. Irrational demands/musts are Ellis's REBT concepts, not Beck's terminology.

questions.stem: Select all that apply. Which of the following are core techniques used in Beck's cognitive therapy?

options.text: Thought records documenting situation, automatic thought, evidence, and balanced thought
Behavioral experiments to test predictions from dysfunctional beliefs
Downward arrow technique to uncover intermediate and core beliefs
Systematic desensitization with progressive muscle relaxation
Free association to uncover unconscious conflicts

questions.explanation: Thought records, behavioral experiments, and the downward arrow technique are all core Beck CBT techniques. Thought records document the cognitive restructuring process. Behavioral experiments test the client's predictions in real-world situations. The downward arrow technique probes beneath automatic thoughts to reveal deeper beliefs. Systematic desensitization is Wolpe's behavioral technique, and free association is Freud's psychoanalytic technique.

questions.stem: Select all that apply. In Meichenbaum's Stress Inoculation Training (SIT), which of the following are the three phases of treatment?
questions.explanation: Meichenbaum's SIT has three phases: (1) Conceptualization -- educating the client about stress, identifying stressors and coping; (2) Skills acquisition and rehearsal -- teaching and practicing coping skills (relaxation, cognitive restructuring, self-instruction); (3) Application and follow-through -- gradually applying skills to increasingly stressful situations with booster sessions. Disputation is Ellis's technique. Transference analysis is psychoanalytic.

questions.stem: Match each cognitive distortion to the client statement that best exemplifies it.

rows.text: 'My friend didn't return my call, so she must hate me.'
'I got one negative comment on my evaluation, so the whole review was terrible.'
'If I make any mistake in this presentation, I'll be fired and my career will be over.'
'My colleague looked stressed today -- it's probably because of something I said.'

questions.explanation: Row 1 = mind reading (assuming the friend's thoughts/feelings without evidence). Row 2 = selective abstraction (focusing on one negative comment while ignoring the larger positive context). Row 3 = catastrophizing (predicting the worst possible chain of outcomes from a minor event). Row 4 = personalization (attributing the colleague's stress to oneself without evidence).

questions.stem: Match each CBT approach to the theorist most closely associated with its development.

rows.text: Cognitive therapy with focus on automatic thoughts, schemas, and Socratic questioning
Rational Emotive Behavior Therapy with the ABC model and direct disputation
Stress Inoculation Training with conceptualization, skills acquisition, and application phases
Problem-solving therapy with five-step structured approach to everyday problems

questions.explanation: Beck: cognitive therapy with automatic thoughts, schemas, Socratic questioning. Ellis: REBT with ABC model and direct disputation. Meichenbaum: Stress Inoculation Training with three phases. D'Zurilla and Goldfried: problem-solving therapy with a five-step structured approach.

questions.stem: For each therapeutic approach, select ALL techniques or concepts that are characteristic of that approach.

columns.text: Self-instructional training and coping skills rehearsal
Brainstorming alternatives and evaluating solution feasibility

questions.explanation: Beck uses Socratic questioning to guide the client's own discovery. Ellis directly disputes irrational beliefs characterized by demands (musts/shoulds). Meichenbaum's SIT incorporates self-instructional training and rehearsal of coping skills across phases. D'Zurilla's problem-solving therapy focuses on brainstorming alternative solutions and systematically evaluating their feasibility.

questions.stem: For each component of a thought record, select ALL elements that correctly belong in that column.

columns.text: The triggering event described in objective, factual terms
The spontaneous cognition and associated emotion rating
Facts supporting and contradicting the automatic thought
A more realistic reappraisal with updated emotion rating

questions.explanation: A thought record has structured columns: (1) Situation -- the objective triggering event; (2) Automatic thought -- the spontaneous cognition with emotion intensity rating; (3) Evidence for and against -- factual evidence supporting and contradicting the thought; (4) Balanced thought -- a more realistic reappraisal with an updated emotion rating showing the change. This structure operationalizes cognitive restructuring.

questions.stem: In Ellis's ABC model, 'A' stands for {{blank1}}, 'B' stands for {{blank2}}, and 'C' stands for {{blank3}}. Ellis's core insight is that {{blank4}} causes C, not A directly.
questions.explanation: Ellis's ABC model: A = Activating event (the trigger), B = Belief (rational or irrational interpretation), C = Consequence (emotional and behavioral result). The core insight of REBT is that B (beliefs) causes C, not A. Events do not directly cause emotional disturbance; our interpretations of events do. Ellis later added D (Disputing) and E (Effective new belief).

questions.stem: Beck's cognitive triad of depression proposes that depressed individuals hold negative views of {{blank1}}, {{blank2}}, and {{blank3}}. In Beck's cognitive model, the deepest level of cognition is called {{blank4}}, which are fundamental beliefs about self, others, and the world that are activated by stressful events.
questions.explanation: Beck's cognitive triad: negative views of the self ('I'm worthless'), the world ('Everything is terrible'), and the future ('Things will never get better'). The deepest level of cognition in Beck's model is core beliefs (schemas), which are fundamental, enduring beliefs activated by stressful events. Automatic thoughts are surface-level; intermediate beliefs are conditional rules/assumptions. 'Irrational demands' is Ellis's terminology.

questions.stem: A 45-year-old woman presents with chronic depression. She reports, 'I'm fundamentally defective. Everyone eventually sees how worthless I am and leaves. There's no point in trying because nothing will ever change.' She avoids social situations, has withdrawn from hobbies, and spends most of her time in bed.

options.text: Core schema of defectiveness activated across relationships
Beck's cognitive triad: negative views of self, world, and future
Irrational demand that others must always approve of her
Unresolved oedipal conflict producing symptom formation
Depression maintained by dysfunctional schemas driving avoidance and withdrawal from positive reinforcement
Generalized anxiety disorder with excessive worry
Borderline personality organization with identity diffusion
Cognitive restructuring using thought records and Socratic questioning to challenge negative automatic thoughts
Behavioral activation to increase engagement with reinforcing activities
Flooding with prolonged exposure to feared social situations

questions.explanation: The client displays Beck's cognitive triad (negative self: 'defective,' negative world: 'everyone leaves,' negative future: 'nothing will change') driven by a core defectiveness schema. Her avoidance and withdrawal create a cycle that maintains depression by reducing access to positive reinforcement. Treatment: cognitive restructuring (thought records, Socratic questioning) to challenge automatic thoughts, and behavioral activation to break the avoidance-withdrawal cycle.

questions.stem: A 30-year-old man is referred for severe test anxiety. He reports, 'If I don't pass this certification exam, it proves I'm completely incompetent. I absolutely must pass on the first attempt or I can't stand it.' He has been avoiding studying because thinking about the exam triggers intense anxiety.

options.text: Demandingness: absolutistic belief that he must pass on the first attempt
All-or-nothing thinking equating exam performance with global self-worth
Adaptive concern about performing well on an important exam
Displacement of anger from authority figures onto the exam
Anxiety driven by irrational beliefs (demandingness, low frustration tolerance, global self-rating) leading to avoidance
Specific phobia of test-taking requiring systematic desensitization
Disputation of irrational beliefs and replacement with rational preferences
Stress Inoculation Training to build coping skills for exam-related stress
Token economy reinforcement for studying behavior
Dream analysis to uncover latent test-related conflicts

questions.explanation: The client shows Ellis's irrational beliefs: demandingness ('I absolutely must pass'), low frustration tolerance ('I can't stand it'), and global self-rating (equating exam failure with being 'completely incompetent'). These irrational beliefs combine with all-or-nothing thinking to produce anxiety and avoidance. Treatment: Ellis's disputation to replace demands with preferences, and Meichenbaum's SIT to build coping skills for exam stress.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that are accurate regarding cognitive-behavioral therapy approaches.
questions.passage: In Beck's cognitive model, [automatic thoughts are the deepest level of cognition, while schemas operate at the surface level and are easily accessible to awareness]. The cognitive triad of depression includes [negative views of the self, the world, and the future]. Ellis developed REBT in 1955, making it [one of the earliest cognitive-behavioral approaches, predating Beck's cognitive therapy]. In Meichenbaum's self-instructional training, [the sequence follows Vygotsky's developmental model, progressing from external adult modeling to covert self-instruction]. Problem-solving therapy was developed by [D'Zurilla and Goldfried, teaching a structured five-step approach to everyday problems]. A key distinction between Beck and Ellis is that [Beck is more directive and confrontational while Ellis relies primarily on guided discovery through Socratic questioning].

highlightableSegments.text: automatic thoughts are the deepest level of cognition, while schemas operate at the surface level and are easily accessible to awareness
negative views of the self, the world, and the future
one of the earliest cognitive-behavioral approaches, predating Beck's cognitive therapy
the sequence follows Vygotsky's developmental model, progressing from external adult modeling to covert self-instruction
D'Zurilla and Goldfried, teaching a structured five-step approach to everyday problems
Beck is more directive and confrontational while Ellis relies primarily on guided discovery through Socratic questioning

questions.explanation: Segments 2, 3, 4, and 5 are accurate. Segment 1 reverses the levels: automatic thoughts are surface-level, schemas are the deepest. Segment 6 reverses Beck and Ellis: Ellis is the more directive and confrontational one (direct disputation), while Beck uses guided discovery through Socratic questioning.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements about cognitive distortions that contain accurate definitions.
questions.passage: Cognitive distortions are systematic errors in thinking identified by Beck. [Selective abstraction involves focusing on one detail taken out of context while ignoring the larger picture]. [Personalization refers to predicting catastrophic outcomes based on minimal evidence]. [All-or-nothing thinking involves viewing situations in only two extreme categories with no middle ground]. [Magnification involves attributing external events to oneself without basis]. [Emotional reasoning involves using one's feelings as evidence for the truth of a belief]. [Overgeneralization involves drawing a broad, sweeping conclusion from a single event or limited evidence].

highlightableSegments.text: Selective abstraction involves focusing on one detail taken out of context while ignoring the larger picture
Personalization refers to predicting catastrophic outcomes based on minimal evidence
All-or-nothing thinking involves viewing situations in only two extreme categories with no middle ground
Magnification involves attributing external events to oneself without basis
Emotional reasoning involves using one's feelings as evidence for the truth of a belief
Overgeneralization involves drawing a broad, sweeping conclusion from a single event or limited evidence

questions.explanation: Segments 1, 3, 5, and 6 are accurate. Segment 2 is wrong: personalization is attributing external events to oneself without basis (the definition given actually describes catastrophizing). Segment 4 is wrong: magnification is inflating the importance of negative events or minimizing positives (the definition given is actually personalization). The definitions of personalization and magnification have been swapped.

questions.stem: Arrange the five steps of D'Zurilla and Goldfried's problem-solving therapy in the correct sequential order.

items.text: Problem orientation -- recognizing problems as normal and adoptable an optimistic, rational approach
Problem definition and formulation -- clearly defining the problem in specific, concrete terms
Generation of alternatives -- brainstorming multiple possible solutions without evaluating them
Decision making -- evaluating each alternative based on feasibility and likely consequences
Solution implementation and verification -- carrying out the chosen solution and monitoring results
Adjustment and generalization -- modifying the approach if needed and applying skills to future problems

questions.explanation: D'Zurilla and Goldfried's problem-solving therapy follows this sequence: (1) Problem orientation (adopting a constructive attitude), (2) Problem definition (specifying the problem concretely), (3) Generation of alternatives (brainstorming without evaluation), (4) Decision making (evaluating and selecting), (5) Implementation and verification (carrying out and monitoring), (6) Adjustment and generalization (modifying as needed and applying broadly).

questions.stem: Arrange the steps of Meichenbaum's self-instructional training in the correct developmental sequence, from earliest to most advanced.

items.text: An adult model performs the task while talking aloud (cognitive modeling)
The child performs the task with the adult's verbal guidance (overt external guidance)
The child performs the task while talking aloud to themselves (overt self-guidance)
The child whispers the instructions to themselves (faded overt self-guidance)
The child uses covert, internal self-instructions (covert self-instruction)
The child independently applies internalized self-instructions to novel situations (generalization)

questions.explanation: Meichenbaum's self-instructional training follows Vygotsky's developmental model of speech internalization: (1) adult cognitive modeling (talking aloud), (2) overt external guidance (child performs with adult's verbal direction), (3) overt self-guidance (child talks aloud to themselves), (4) faded self-guidance (whispered), (5) covert self-instruction (internal speech), (6) generalization to novel situations.

questions.stem: A randomized controlled trial compares CBT with a waitlist control for moderate depression. The Beck Depression Inventory (BDI-II) is administered at multiple time points. Higher scores indicate more severe depression (clinical cutoff = 20).
questions.question: What do these data demonstrate about the effectiveness of CBT for depression?

options.text: CBT and waitlist control produce equivalent outcomes, suggesting spontaneous remission
CBT produces clinically significant improvement, with the treatment group crossing below the clinical cutoff by week 8, while the control group shows minimal change
The waitlist control group shows faster initial improvement than the CBT group
Neither group shows meaningful change over the 16-week period

questions.explanation: The CBT group shows steady, substantial improvement from 32 (severe) to 10 (minimal), crossing below the clinical cutoff of 20 by week 8. The waitlist control group shows only minimal change (31 to 27), remaining above the clinical cutoff throughout. This pattern is consistent with the robust evidence base for CBT in depression, showing specific treatment effects beyond the passage of time.

questions.stem: A researcher tracks changes in the frequency of cognitive distortions and corresponding depression severity across a course of Beck's cognitive therapy. Both measures are assessed weekly.
questions.question: What relationship between cognitive distortions and depression do these data support?

options.text: Cognitive distortions and depression are unrelated, as their trajectories are independent
Depression decreases first, followed by a lagged reduction in cognitive distortions
Reductions in cognitive distortions closely parallel reductions in depression severity, consistent with Beck's cognitive model
Cognitive distortions increase while depression decreases, suggesting a compensatory mechanism

questions.explanation: Both measures show closely parallel downward trajectories: cognitive distortion frequency drops from 42 to 10 while depression severity drops from 30 to 9. This parallel pattern supports Beck's cognitive model, which posits that distorted thinking drives depressive symptoms and that modifying dysfunctional cognitions produces improvements in mood. The tight coupling between cognitive change and symptom change is consistent with the theoretical mechanism of cognitive therapy.

questions.stem: Categorize each clinical example according to the cognitive distortion it best represents.

items.text: 'I got a B on the test, so I'm a complete failure as a student.'
'I stuttered once during my speech, so everyone thought it was terrible.'
'If I don't get this promotion, I'll lose my house and end up homeless.'
'Either I do this perfectly or it's not worth doing at all.'
'My date canceled -- I'll never find anyone and will always be alone.'
'If I make a mistake at work, I'll be fired, I'll never get another job, and my life will be ruined.'

questions.explanation: All-or-nothing thinking: viewing things in only two categories (B = complete failure; perfect or not worth doing). Catastrophizing: predicting the worst possible chain of outcomes (no promotion leads to homelessness; one mistake leads to total ruin). Overgeneralization: drawing broad conclusions from a single event (one stutter means everyone thought it was terrible; one canceled date means lifelong loneliness).

questions.stem: Categorize each therapeutic technique according to the CBT approach it is most closely associated with.

items.text: Thought records documenting evidence for and against automatic thoughts
Direct disputation of absolutistic musts and demands
Self-instructional training following a speech internalization sequence
Downward arrow technique to uncover core beliefs
Distinguishing rational preferences from irrational demands
Three-phase stress inoculation: conceptualization, skills acquisition, application
Behavioral experiments to empirically test dysfunctional predictions
ABCDE framework for identifying and challenging beliefs

questions.explanation: Beck: thought records, downward arrow technique, behavioral experiments. Ellis: direct disputation, rational preferences vs. irrational demands, ABCDE framework. Meichenbaum: self-instructional training and three-phase stress inoculation training.
